titleStmt.title: SII 2.89: original edition by V. Venkayya
No. 89. ON A NICHE OF THE WEST ENCLOSURE. No. 35 of 1897.

summary.p: This inscription records the gift of two ornaments to the shrine of Piḷḷaiyār Gaṇapatiyār by a merchant living in one of the suburbs of Tanjore. The gift was made “until the 29th year (of Rājarājadēva).”

revisionDesc.change: Further conversion of digital encoding to DHARMA encoding scheme according to EGD (Encoding Guide for Diplomatic Editions)
Conversion of digital encoding to DHARMA encoding scheme according to EGD (Encoding Guide for Diplomatic Editions)

div.p:
svasti śrīḥ .
tañcāvūrk
kūṟṟattuttañ
cāvūrppuṟampaṭi maṭikai Irukkum viyāpāri
nārāyaṇaṉ kāmappaiceṭṭi Ikkaṇapatiyā
rkku yāṇṭu Irupattoṉpatāvatu varai kuṭu
tta ratnaṅkaḷ dakṣiṇameruviṭaṅkan Eṉṉuṅkal
lāl niṟai Eṭuttum poṉ Āṭavallāṉ
Eṉṉuṅkallāl niṟai Eṭuttum kallil veṭ
ṭiṉa .—1 caṅkiṭṭu Aṭaitta kaṟkaṇṭu Oṉṟilttaṭavikkaṭṭiṉa paḷiṅku
Iraṇṭum poṉṉiṉ kāmpum Uṭpaṭa niṟai nāṟkaḻañcukku vilai kācu O
ṉṟey kāl [.—2*] tiraḷmaṇivaṭam Oṉṟu poṉ Oṉpatiṉ kaḻañcey mūṉṟu
mañcāṭi .. 3

Hail ! Prosperity ! The jewels presented until the twenty-ninth year (of the king's reign) to thisThe shrine mentioned in the preceding inscription is evidently meant. (shrine of) Gaṇapatiyār by Nārāyaṇaṉ Kāmappai-śeṭṭi, a merchant living in the suburban maḍigaiThe exact significance of this word is not clear to me. The word does not occur either in Winslow's Tamil Dictionary or in Gundert's Malayāḷam Dictionary. Perhaps it is connected with the Tamil maḷigai, ‘a grocery shop,’ and denotes a street or quarter of the town where grocers' shops were located. of Tañjāvūr in Tañjāvūr-kūṟṟam, were engraved (i.e. recorded) on stone after (they) had been weighed by the stone called Dakshiṇamēru-Viṭaṅkaṉ and after the gold had been weighed by the stone called Āḍavallāṉ.

2. One kaṟkaṇḍuKaṟkaṇḍu means ‘sugar-candy,’ which does not suit here. I do not understand the term caṅkiṭṭu aṭaitta kaṟkaṇṭu. The word kaṇṭu occurs in paragraph 9 on p. 432, below. filled with a conch (?)—weighing, inclusive of the two crystals fastened on (it) and of the handle made of gold, four kaṛañju,—valued at one kāśu and a quarter.
3. One string of round beads, (consisting) of nine kaṛañju and three mañjāḍi of gold.
Digital edition of SII 2.89 by converted to DHARMA conventions by Emmanuel Francis.
